review_blob: Brownish, unfiltered lightly steeped tea water colour with a buoyant thick off white head. Easy drinking ale that is simplistic but rich with savory and sweet aromas. Malty lingering flavour with a long lasting mild fruity green apple residue. At 6.8% alc./vol it is a satisfying middle of the road North American pale ale.
UPDATED: APR 7, 2016

Bland, overly ascetic and light aroma. Clear, foamless filtered lemon straw colour. Brand, light tasting at first followed by a sweet sugary aftertaste. Uninspiring thirst quencher with little to no character.

Right out of the bottle (650ml) lots of wet banana bread batter scents. Dark red tea water with a thick grayish off-white head that looks like frothy latte. Some spicy notes and a bit of cloves with a heavy yeasty base in the aroma. Wet or sweet taste and very fruity even dark raisin flavours. Upfront bold high gravity profile balance and refreshing.
Brownish head on top of a ruddy red unfiltered ale. Lots of malty chocolate aronas. Sweet tasting malt finish. Sparing and not overtly strong.

Powerfully aromatic, grassy wet hops to begin with some yeast and light banana notes and a mild spice scent. Unfiltered, creamy, pastel appeal with a thick snowy head. Bold and bitter and favours the fan of hops. Balanced with citrus and grapefruit flavours. The aftertaste is sturdy and lasts a while.

Pours out of the bottle with a thin white head that creates a tidy ring of large bubbles. The hoppy aroma is very apparent and balanced by some sweet caramel malty and vanilla notes. Crisp, refreshing first taste. Bready, wheat flavours upfront, stays sweet through the sip. There is a hoppy, graasy character at the finish. Easy to drink.

Reddish orange colour thin white head of tiny bubbles. Unfiltered cloudy appearance. A lot of bread and wheat in the first waft followed by some caramel sweetness and even some bitter burnt butter notes. The first taste is sweet and malty with a hint of bland citrus. Fairly simple body a quick oily sweet mouthfeel. An easy drinking lager.

Opener on Jan 17th 2016 from a 500ml bottle. The brett is apparent upfront as this ale starts with a strong yeasty aroma, some barnish scents with wet hoppy notes. The brilliant sunshinr colour and thin white head brighten this beer. Mellow bitter taste at first but well balanced. Lemon zesty flavours and some light barely apparent mint notes makes this beer slightly astringent. Drink this beer with spicy meat and rich cheeses.

Almost a neon amber colour, bright white head. Wet green apple sour cider aroma and some brown sugar scents. Effervescent and quickly fading mouth feel. A sour, malty, cider taste and cloying drying minor bitterness in the end. A complex and intriguing pilsner of a different generation.
beer_name: Flying Monkeys Mythology Canadian Golden Pilsner

review_blob: The aroma has a wet character, fresh hops, some cloves and spice with subtle hints of banana bread. Clear, filtered lacquer brown colour. Tight off white stable head. Nutty, bitter upfront lessened by a following milk chocolate bitterness. Total mouth fulfilling and complex flavour, with a lingering after taste on the back of the tongue. Its my job to explain the experience of drinking the ale and if I could opine for a second, and comment not just on the experience but also the enjoyment of the ale I must say Tank house Ale is one of my all time favourite beers. Sessionable, confident, complex and so very delicious!

Carrot orange colour with an orange off white head. Frothy head that sticks around and caps the unfiltered body. Fresh wet hoppy aromas swith some citrus notes balanced in the flavours. The bitterness is subtle at first and reveals itself quickly and then fades.
beer_name: Creemore Springs Mad & Noisy Hops & Bolts India Pale Lager

review_blob: Dark black unfiltered stout. Thick brown foam head that dissipates quickly. Dark bittersweet chocolate aroma some faint berry fruit notes. Fairly dry and simple flavour chocolate and malt. Alittle yeasty and spiriteous. Pleasing enduring aftertaste.
beer_name: Muskoka Winter Beard Double Chocolate Cranberry Stout

review_blob: Dark, non-transparent colour. Hardy off white head that leaves a bead of tight tiny bubble lacing. Delicious burnt toast charring aroma, complimented by the same burnt or heavily roasted malt flavour in the first taste. Bittersweet chocolate and some coffee notes follow. It does change as it warms in the glass and develops a faint barely noticible yeast character with mild sour hints.  Dry bitter flavour finish sublimated by a malty end with some vanilla. Easy drinking porter.

Murky brown unfiltered body with an effluent off white head of large foam bubbles about 3.5 cm thick that lasts for the entire glass. Aromas of wet banana bread dough, some spiciness at first and an aged oak wood tinge in the end. A complex flavour of gingerbread, some yeast and deep demerara sugar. Bold malt and bold bitter profile. Mouthfeel is oily and lingering but the whole experience is remarkably balanced and in the end smooth and satisfying.

Rose, red, clear, crisp filtered colour with a sparse off white foam head. Lots of Christmas aromas, fruit cake, dried fruits, and gingerbread. Sweet malty rum flavour upfront. It Lingers a bit on the tongue with a subtle very subtle bitter hop note. Light tasting considering it a high gravity ale at 9% by volume.

Clear reddish-tan colour, filtered with a large off white crown of foam. Grassy aroma as it poured out of the can some caramel notes with typical IPA hop character. Creamy smooth approach, balanced well between hops and sweet malt like molasses flavour. A mild bitterness makes this an easy drinking IPA.

Pale unfiltered lemony colour with a full foamy white head. Smells of peaches and stone fruit and refined sugar. Lots of peaches in the first taste. Light and Bubbly sweet tanginess. Finishes with fruity aftertaste.
Unfiltered, ruby tea water colour with almost no head. Lots of wet pumpkin aroma and some spice and bread notes. Sweet pumpkin and citrus orange flavours. Easy drinking refreshing ale.
beer_name: Black Creek Barrel Aged Spiced Pumpkin Ale

review_blob: Straw golden colour fast fading white head. Clear as a bell. Unfiltered. Lots of bananas in the initial aroma, a little bit of bread crust and yeast notes. The white sugar sweetness is unrequited because there is almost no bitterness or hop flavours. The sharp carbonation makes this beer clear, crisp and quick to wash the taste out of your mouth.

Initial aromas of dry golden straw. Highly carbonated with large rising bubbles and a plate of white head on top. Malty and bitter at the start followed by a dry grassy hop finish. Very sharp and refreshing with a warming finish.

Bright plastic lemon shade of lager. Warm bread flour smell. Filtered clear with out much of a head but a lasting small white ring of tiny bubbles. Grassy malt taste at first taken away with a wet sugary finish. It has a quick sharp bitter quality. Easy drinking American lager, similar to other mass market session lagers.

Maple red colour thick off white foamy head. Yeasty hop aromas. Bright green-apple flavour with a caramel sweet sugar maltiness with some lingering soft spices on the aftertaste. An easy drinking balanced English ale.

Unfiltered reddish hue. Thin, quickly dispensed tan-lemon head. Candy sweet aroma a little yeasty with some maltiness. Sweet upfront taste like refined sugar, wheat notes with some subtle citrus flavours Complex well balanced and refreshing.

Bright, light, brown colour. Filtered, clear white foamy head. Nearly offensive aroma slighty spoiled almost rotten vegetables on the nose. Bland, faintly bitter oily finish. Simple cidery grassy beer.

One and a half inch thick, creamy, porcelain dense, brown, foam head that dissipates to a plated ring of tiny and medium size bubbles. Woodstain brown/black colour. Opaque so its hard to identify if it is filtered or not. Heavy aromas of cold wet pasta. Faint notes of dark berries and even yeasty hints. Its dark chocolate, bittersweet and off balance. Initially sharp and sweet, and malty then offset with coffee flavours. Ends dry mouth with a lingering aftertaste of licorice and spice.
Filtered, bright, with a thin short lived white head. Twany red, malt and honey aromas. Sweet upfront flavour, a tinge of hop bitterness. A bready malt balanced refreshing ale.

Cloudy orange colour, with an off white and orange tinted head of giant bubbles. Notes of sweet honey and floral aromas. Orange peel bitterness with balanced citrus flavours. Sharp, tart and lingering aftertaste on a wet sweet mouthfeel.

Looks like cola when you pour it and it stays with the same type of lasting head. Filtered, tea water colour. Mild chocolate malty and hay like aromas. First taste is light and sweet, an easy drinking lager, with subtle brown sugar and nut flavours. Underwhelming.

Black, unfiltered stout pours out of the can like coffee grounds out of the bottom of the pot and leaves a spongy brown foam. Lots of chocolate cake and vanilla aromas upfront and smells of sweet icing sugar. Bitter chocolate flavour with a light licorice spiciness with cherry cordial. Lingers on the palate, well balanced with and then finishes the way it starts cordially bitter, but balanced and fulfilling.
beer_name: Double Trouble French Press Vanilla Stout

review_blob: Dark ruby rich colour. Small brownish head of small tight bubbles. Strong chocolate aroma, neat licorice flavour, lingering bitterness and long lasting complex profile.
beer_name: Flying Monkeys Netherworld Cascadian Dark Ale

review_blob: Deep space dark black pours like burnt oil dripping out of a rusted ford. Thick frothy brown butter colour head. Sturdy bubbles and a long ring a lacing. Spiritus oak aroma with some astringency backed by heavy nites of offee and dark macerated fruits like raisins and dates. Smooth and warming balanced flavour, easy drinking. Aged oaky flavour, faintly bitter in the end which clarifies and prepares the palate for a spicy charring finish.
beer_name: Sawdust City Long, Dark Voyage to Uranus

review_blob: Clear, filtered bright straw colour. Mostly apple and cider in the fruity aroma, complimented by straw and malt notes. Easy drinking and refreshing if you like sweet lagers. Clean crisp finish and a dry mouthfeel which makes it very sessionable. Great with pepperoni mushroom and green olive pizza.

Ruddy unfiltered brown orange colour. Tan off-white large bubble foam head. Mild subdued aroma of mainly apple notes which is doubled down in the flavour of the first taste. Slight hoppiness as the brew reaches the back of the tongue followed by a toasted malt finish.
beer_name: Samuel Smiths Organic / Old Brewery Pale Ale

review_blob: From the 500ml bottle this ale pours fine and thin without a crown of head. Light fragile bubble dissipate quickly and leave a white ring of lacing. Bright fresh green aroma. Notes of toffee and cake batter with some fruitiness. Upfront bitter taste with a balanced hoppy after taste that come about late. Green, fresh wet flavour with a warming sensation to finish.

Amber orange hue, luscious head of foamy bubbles followes by a tidy ring of dissipated lacing. A little banana note complimented by a yeasty bread aroma off the top. Some spice as the nose warms. Sweet toffee along with macerated fruit and spice flavours of apricot and nutmeg. Syrupy, wet, lingering and persistent mouthfeel.

Cloud ripe banana peel colour. Foamy, bright, white, thick head with long continuance and a hearty rim lacing. Lots of quick rising bubbles. Fresh spiced aroma with fresh grapefruit notes and a dry straw hoppiness with a barn-like overtone. Creamy approach with light citrus flavours of orange and lemon. Its sweet malty and bitter at the start which is quelled by the carbonation then balanced by the late taste of hops. Dry mouth feel with a late aftertaste.

Strawberry blonde unfiltered cloudy brew. Fine lacing of tiny bubbles. First aromas are fresh peeled green banana, grapefruit and some spicy notes. Banana bread taste upfront and in the late aftertaste. Mild pepper tinge with lemon and bright malty sour sweetness. Fairly crisp through and through. Balanced with a pleasing effervescence which leaves with a sparkling finish.

Dark rich sunburnt straw colour. Unfiltered and lightly carbonated body. Giant bubbles in the thick sturdy head. Powdered sugar aroma and spiritus oaky notes. Smooth, refreshing approach, crisp first taste, complimented by a slightly oily mouth feel. Honey flavor with nutty and baked bread notes.

Clear straw colour. Right from the can vigorously poured to create a tall think foamy head, quintessential lager looking glass of beer. Dry grassy aroma with a faint creamy scent with green vegetables and sugar notes with herbal undertones. Taste is very sweet upfront almost overbearing, hints of simple syrup and refined sugar, the bitter after taste is far too subtle for my palate.

Pint at The Craft in Liberty Village Toronto. Golden brown colour unfiltered and a little cloudy. Well carbonated small bubbly head. Floral aroma toasted wheat and cooked pasta notes. Easy refreshing beer, woody and sweet with clean crisp mouthful. Enjoyable with a burger and mushrooms.

Starts with caramel brown sugar aroma that is sweet at first and then offset by an oak wood scent. Clear filtered bubbly orange brown colour. Thin foam with little to no head. Upfront sweetness the latellr develops into a lingering after taste of brown sugar. The bitterness of the Hops come well after the swig is swallowed, kinda grassy mild and well balanced bitter sweetness.

Dark golden colour with a thin lacing plate of foam. Dried uncooked pasta, with subtle roasted vanillia aroma. Smooth with a sudden bitterness upfront, oily wet approach on the tounge. Lingering finish with a full mouth after taste and numbing bitterness.

Candle wax and field berries like ripe ready strawberries. Thin barely consistent foam. Straw sweet and easy to enjoy, there is a distinct enjoyable after taste reminiscent of what beer should taste like, thank you Stella for trying.
Light bright colour. Thin creamy head. Wet barn aroma thin flavour refreashing. Easy to drink with light mild cheese and salami

Crystal clean pale colour with bleach white thick foamy head. Fast rising Champagne style bubbles. Skunky green aroma of yeast. Light easy drinking refreshment, clean upfront taste, mild and underwhelming in a good way. Late bitter herbalness for a balancing contrast. Great with spicy curry.

500ml bittle . LCBO Liberty Village. Unfiltered red autumn sunset colour. Thin light head turns into a thin lacing of big bubbles. A lot of heavy semi-sweet chocolate aromas, and honey. Chicolate . Easy drinking and refreshing ale an fading taste of savory cake batter and a provencial bitterness way on the back of the tongue. Very tasty dessert beer.
beer_name: Cassel Golden Rail Honey Brown Ale

review_blob: 330ml bottle, LCBO, Toronto. This was a gusher even though I let it sit and settle on the coffee table before I uncapped it and tried to pour it. The initial foam was thick with large off white brownish bubbles. They disipated to a lacing ring around the glass quickly. Citrus, Florida orange, light straw aromas with upfront notes of stone fruit and some dried apricot flavor. There are hints of spicy sweetness and the taste lingers in the mouth like a sugary glaze.

Caution light colour, unfiltered, pale lager. Sturdy thick ring of bubbly foam. Stale lemon aroma complimented with salt water. Spicy flavour of the top. Quick mouth feel and pleasing slightly bitter taste.

Ruddy golden straw colour. Highly carbonated, thin dense ring of white cream hued foam. Big bubbly liquid. Aromas of baked goods, white flour and pie crust, light toffee scent. Easy drinking but still a bold ale, fast flavour and clean mouth feel. Some fresh grassy notes, slightly herbal. Overall a decent effort at a typical north American ale. Drink it and enjoy a fruit platter with honeydew, grapes and some ground nuts.
